description.para: Etiquette is a knowledge of good manners and social behaviour. It is of much greater use amongst the higher classes than amongst the peasantry, where no-one really cares which fork they use to eat their meal with, as long as a meal is there to be eaten.

It may be used to know how to address someone of rank, how to flirt with a noble Lady without offending her, or how to behave at a joust or banquet. It is normally based on intelligence, but may use charisma (especially for courtly flirting or flattery).

examples.example: How to greet a person correctly
How to eat without embarassing yourself
Choosing a suitable gift

description.para: Knowledge of how to play games of chance. Used with charisma for bluffing, intelligence to figure out the odds of something, or perception to spot cheating. Does not really help if the game is totally chance based.
Knowledge of, and skill at playing a game such as chess or Hnefatafl. A skill is required for each game played, though similar games may allow half skill. This is based on intelligence.
The simplist way to find the winner for a game, is for both opponents to roll their skill, and the highest roll wins. If it is desired to play out the game in more detail, then proceed as follows.

Each opponent makes a skill check each turn of the game. If one exceeds the other by five or more, then they gain an advantage. Each advantage gained gives +3 to the skill check next turn. On gaining the fourth advantage, the player is considered the winner. If the player with the advantage looses a turn, then they loose a level of advantage.

examples.example: Knowing the rules to a game
Playing a game reasonably well

description.para: The skill of reading lips. Each 10 rolled gives an equivalent point of language skill. There may be penalties for distance, or partial visibility.
Disguising someone to look like someone else.

A skill which covers many forms of social skills, including oratory, poetry and singing. It may be used to rouse a crowd, invent some poetry on the spot, or remember a poem or song well enough to recite or sing it.

The mood of the audience can be affected with either song, poetry or oratory. The performer matches their skill roll against the will of the audience. If the audience can be treated as a crowd, take the average will and roll once for the whole audience (a vocal few will tend to lead the silent majority). Success by the performer will mean the crowd listens to what the performer says, and will think about it, though their opinion isn't shifted greatly. For each full 10 the performer beats the will of the crowd, the crowd's mood is shifted one category.
When singing or reciting poetry, the mood of the audience can be shifted, sometimes considerably. This can be done subtly, though it takes an evening of performance to carry it out.
A more direct way to sway an audience is through oratory. This is quicker and more direct then by choice of song, but is also pretty blatent.

examples.example: Sing without inflicting pain on listeners. Less than this may get the character forcibly removed from the stage.
Sing well enough to impress the audience, though not in a way that will be particularly remembered.
Sing very well. The singer will be well received, and probably kept around for more of the same. The mood of the audience can be shifted subtly.
The singer will be spoken of for months to come, and people will be most eager to please. The mood of the audience can be shifted noticeably.
All others will be compared (probably unfavourably) to the singer, who will be heralded as a master of their art. The singer pretty much has control over the mood of the audience.

description.para: The skill of playing musical instruments, whether they are a drum, a flute or a harp.

examples.example: Play without sending people running for cover
Play in tune with others
Play very well

description.para: The ability to dance gracefully and to music. Used with agility. If the character is performing erotic dancing, then they may add any bonuses for beauty to their agility.
The ability to draw or paint competently. Used with dexterity, or with intelligence to try and accurately draw some scene from memory.

skill.name: Teach
skill.description: The ability to teach another person, and train them in the use of a skill. See the Campaign section for details on training.

description.para: Covers a multitude of skills involved with trading, including bartering, and having some clue as to the value of goods.

The skill of seducing people. This gives knowledge of how to dress, how to behave and what to say when trying to arose sexual desire in someone. It also gives skill in bed. It is used to persuade someone to have sex with the character when they wouldn't otherwise want to. If they do want to, then no skill roll is required.

Charm can be used in its place, though the roll is halved. However, it is often better to use charm more indirectly, to improve the relationship over a period of time. Seduction is more suited to one night stands or simply distracting someone momentarily.

The skill of dealing with the intrigues of a political court. With it, it is possible to find out relationships within the court, and to obtain information from people, or even to spread information without it being obvious that the plotter is trying to spread information.

examples.example: Detect broad allegiences in a group

description.para: Making threats in order to scare someone. Can be used with either strength or charisma. The former requires the visible threat of physical force to back it up, the latter requires some believable threat.

It is an opposed intimidation roll versus the target's will and bravery, modified by circumstance. A moderate success will cause the target to pause to think, a good success to back off, and an excellent success to run. Note that most people will decide to back down anyway if they are facing an obviously dangerous threat, regardless of how brave they are and regardless of the result of any intimidation.
Guile may be used in place of Intimidation, though the roll is halved.

examples.example: Intimidator is in a position of great weakness.
Intimidator is in an obviously weak position.
Intimidator seems to be in a weak position.
Intimidator and target are about matched.
Intimidator seems to have the advantage.
Intimidator obviously is stronger.
Intimidator overwhelms the target.

description.para: Streetwise is similar to intrigue, though is more suited to life amongst the criminal classes. With it, comes knowledge of how to survive on the street, how to gain the trust of those who live on the wrong side of the law, as well as how to find them in the first place.

skill.name: Boating
skill.description: Being able to use a small oared boat. Based on intelligence for judging travel conditions, strength for speed or dexterity for fine navigation.

examples.example: Row a boat in a straight line in calm conditions
Row a boat in choppy conditions
Row a boat in rough conditions (open sea)
Very rough conditions
Row in a storm

skill.name: Falconry
skill.description: The skill of training, caring for and hunting with falcons and similar birds of prey.

skill.name: Hunting
skill.description: The skill of training, caring for and hunting with hounds.

skill.name: Ride
skill.description: The ability to ride, normally a horse. A different skill is needed for different types of animals (horses and ponies would be the same skill, a Griffin another skill). As well as enabling you to remain mounted, it grants a bonus to combat skills when mounted.

description.para: Handling a team of animals, either pack animals or horses or oxen pulling wagons. Care, feeding and pacing, as well as being able to distribute load across the team to get the maximum efficiency.

The survival skill has to be specialised in a specific terrain type, including desert, plains, arctic, mountains, woodlands, jungle, coastal and swamp. One specialisation is gained for free when the skill is first bought, the others cost 3 points for each extra terrain.
With it, the character is able to find food and shelter, track game, and know how to travel safely and quickly through that type of terrain.

Foraging. When foraging for food, it takes four hours for each roll. Each five over the difficulty allows enough food to be found for another two people. If more food is found than is needed, then the forager as the option of stopping early as soon as enough food has been found. Assume that food is found at a consistent rate through the time period.
Hunting. Similar to foraging, it takes four hours for each attempt to hunt game.

Tracking. Survival can be used to track others by their footprints and other signs. It is possible to estimate the type of animal, their number and how long it has been since the tracks were made. Of course, it can be used to track people as well.

examples.example: Find a suitable shelter
Forage for food for one person
Good conditions
Poor conditions
Very poor conditions (e.g. winter)
Trying to forage in arctic or desert
Trying to forage in mountains or swamp

description.para: The ability to move in water without drowning or panicking. Basically, a waterborne version of the athletics skill.
Handling a sea going vessel. This is very different from boating, which is limited to coastal or river boats.
Being able to turn useless scrap into something useful. Used with intelligence. Covers finding, planning and building, though skills such as carpentry or blacksmith may be needed as well.
